I can remember a situation where someone who uses Kodi (player) combined with Plex (media server) in a local network sent me an error in which an url like the following got interpreted wrong because of the local ip address:

http://127.0.0.1:8080/image/image%3A%2F%2Fhttp%253a%252f%252f127.0.0.1%253a32400%252fphoto%252f%253a%252ftranscode%253fwidth%253d1920%2526height%253d1920%2526minSize%253d1%2526upscale%253d0%2526url%253d%252flibrary%252fmetadata%252f1896%252fthumb%252f1569782004%2526X-Plex-Token%253dXScJLJbUdcybNXFyHLuv

Should there be a test, that putIfAbsent  does not overwrite an existing file?
So

do a put with contentA
do a putIfAbsent with contentB
do a get and assert contentA

This is returning the wrong value.
If putIfAbsent does not change the value, then this function should return the old value, not the parameter.

Maybe, this function should return a boolean:

return true, iff the file was changed
That would make implementing putIfAbsentAndGet easier.
The idea behind of this method follows the ExpiringCacheMap implementation. That is why we have a void putIfAbsent(...) and a byte[] putIfAbsentAndGet(...) method.

But then the signature should be:
byte[] putIfAbsentAndGet(String key, Supplier<byte[]> action)

and the action should only be called, if the value is absent.

I would remove this method and only support a method taking a Duration parameter (i.e. the method below). The issue with long/int values is always that you do not know the unit so you have to document it in either the variable name or JavaDoc. If you don't do any (like this method) you have to inspect the code. With the Duration type you never have to worry about this.
The class doesn't look thread safe. So you may want to mention this here.
